THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VII.

JANUARY 9, 1903.

No. 6.

THE WORTH OF KNOWING ONE'S SELF.
HIS season of the year brings the business man a time for counting up the
.debit and credit columns in order to ascertain where he stands and to
learn the strength of his position; with him it is a literal stock taking and
settlement of his affairs for a new year. With us, as students, it is a period of
renewed resolution to live nearer the ideals which we have set for ourselves
either in scholarship or in refinement of life or in other mental occupations
with which our life is brought into immediate contact. The student comes to
college to learn the meaning of introspection; to investigate the bearing which
things outside of himself have towards his own inner mental being; to grasp in
some limited measure the significance of the great world drama which has been
Playing from eternity and whose finale, whose denouement is that "grand event
towards which the whole creation moves." No wonder, therefore, if at this
Opening of a new year we moralize and reflect upon what we are, why we are
here and ask ourselves whither we are tending. Like the merchant we take
an inventory, although of quite another kind than his. The result of our reck
oning should be a balance of what points of strength we possess against the
Points of weakness. As human beings we are a bundle of forces that resist,
that overcome and which finally spend themselves in resistance. Powers of
mind and of body go hand in hand, so to speak, through life guided with
varying degrees of mastership according to the individual contesting them. As
our physical forces wane our mental strength, toward our later life, should
exhibit a firmness and suppleness in direct ratio to our years and accompany
our failing bodies to brighten their existence and raise them from bitterness.
The declining age of a man who has trusted his sensual life for satisfaction,
whether in business or pleasure or idle ease, must be, logically, physical and
mental wretchedness. Now, realizing ourselves as endowed with these ele.
ments of strength which, by some inscrutable law, must spend themselves, must
objectify themselves in visible or rather tangible demonstration, we can reckon
with ourselves as to what parts of our being need more attention than others.
In other words, what are our points of weakness; what forces in our nature are
liable to show least resistance. The human frame, as we call it, falls asunder
not by the utter collapse of all the parts—bones, muscles and nerves—but owing
to the frailty of a single weakness, which entails entire dissolution and which
the forces of the system collectively cannot stay. Any material object, in like
manner, follows precisely the same law. In the moral world the phenomena of
strength and weakness also appears. It may be the Greeks meant to convey a
lesson to their youth of the importance of watching the weak point in character
by the portrayal of Hercules writhing under a tunic which his world-lifting

2

THE NEWS-LETTER•

strength could not remove. Or the picture of Achilles might have afforded the
same moral when that flower of Greek military prowess was made to meet death
at the hands of Paris who happened to direct the arrow against his invulnerable
body. The hero fell because his heel had not been bathed in the stream whose
waters had saved him from ten thousand arrows hitherto. It may be also that
Samson's career and its sequel conveys a meaning similar to that of Hercules
or Achilles. We can infer that if these giants of myth and history fell at the
point of their greatest weakness, then our lives are subject to the same general
conditions as theirs. The unexpected, the unforseen contingencies are those
which, appearing suddenly as they do, strike at us and may prove too much for
the resistance we can offer them. As students, we need strength to sustain the
courage of conviction, and very frequently at times when, unawares, we stand
confronted with a difficulty that only immediate courage can surmount.
There is a moral sang-froid as well as a mental. Not that a man is to burden
himself with a suspicion of danger impending, and to let the dread of it cast a
cloud over his life-----on the contrary—to face with calmness any emergency that
may arise and despatch it cheerfully. A coward walks backwards into greater
dangers frequently than he would if he went forward, simply because he can see
where he is going w hen he faces the trouble he has to meet and might avert it
largely. One of the forces we cultivate in college life is perseverance, which
is a phase of bravery; bravery, because after efforts made and repeated almost
to the point of physical pain we succeed in overturning and -laying out" the
difficulty that baffles during long hours. Milton is said to have passed scarcely

training we receive at college,
that responsibiliiy falls to guide the forces inherent in our nature along the lines
of courage, perseverance and restraint; to make us masters of ourselves and
husband our energies according to reason; to teach us the lesson of self confidence plus a tranquility of bearing that marks a gentleman. Then,once started
in the direction of these attainments we grow into the educated man if
though we forget every word of Latin and Greek that we ever
thumbed out of a lexicon. If this short paper were a fragment of a treatise on
ethics which it is obviously not, the argument might prove how such a training
of the forces in a man's self reacted upon him and the race at large to the making of a better community in which he should chance to live. The important
point of all is that, adding to his common sense, (which if Ile lack, no eduction
were better in his case) the results gained from his intercourse with instructors
and fellow students and from conscientious painstaking with the very few books
rerched in three years' study, a student should go into the world with a
thoroughly healthful realization of his own strength and weakness and should
be prepared to stand his ground cheerfully and firmly. In the natural course of
events a student, when once left to his own resources ought to develope and
survive as against one who has never been apprised of his failings; his standard
of what a man is being higher than that of his unlettered neighbor requires of him
greater action and should guard him against the shocks of experience by leading him to resist them with equanimity. Fortitude can cope with odds and bear
defeat; brute strength gives way almost immediately on meeting a force but
slightly greater than its own—the one is intelligent strength while the other
lacks intelligence, and the college man who leaves his Alma Mater a stranger
to the meaning of this has to begin life on the level of boyhood.

THE CHRISTMAS TRIP OF THE MUSICAL CLUBS.
44froHAT! going to the Eastern Shore?"
.
This was the disgusted comment of most of the men when they
heard that the management of the University Glee, Banjo, and
Mandolin Clubs had decided to take in Cambridge, Easton, and Salisbury this
year, instead of the usual jaunt to the Valley of Virginia. Most of the men,
however, had evidently never experienced true Eastern Shore hospitality before, and a pleasant surprise awaited them, for the trip was the most enjoyable
Christmas trip ever taken by the clubs, and the most successful, artistically and
financially.
The clubs, numbering 29 musicians of no mean ability, left Baltimore for
Cambridge Monday, December 29th, on the steamer "Avalon." The journey
down the bay was not without incident The development of certain athletic
tendencies'by one of the heretofore solely literary and social lights of the clubs
merely goes to subs,antiate the fact that a college education certainly does
broaden one's scope.
When the clubs arrived at Cambridge, the men were invited to stay with
many of the prominent old families there, and, of course, had a royal time.
Three dances in twenty hours ought to be a record, if it isn't. But even greater
than the number of dances were the attractions and charms of Cambridge's
beauteous daughters. The men, partfcularly one of them, completely lost their
hearts in this old storehouse of Dorchester County's history.
The next place visited was Easton The same cordial welcome awaited
the clubs here. After the concert, which was the best of the three, Mrs. Os—
wald Tilghman gave a fine dance, lasting well on into the New Year, at her
residence. The house was a splendid one for the inevitable tele-a-tete, and the
men made the best of their opportunities.
To the accompaniment of sobs from the fair maidens, the men took their
leave of Easton Thursday morning. Our manager was so broken up at parting
that he forgot most of his belongings, and had to return for them later. The
trip to Salisbury was pleasant, the engine at times attaining the remarkable
speed of iso
miles an hour. Contrary to the precedent of all other Christmas
trips, the prevailing card-game wfis whist. Some of the upper-clasmen devoted
part of their time to the study of the education of the young, and all that one
had to do when an attendant was wanted was to blow a whistle, and a freshman
immediately ran up to get his orders.
The afternoon at Salisbury was spent in making calls and drinking eggnogg. The certainly know how to brew it across the bay.
The crowd at the Salisbury concert was the largest one of the trip. After
the concert was over, a most enjoyable Eastern Shore dinner was given by
Richard N. Jackson, '05, son of Ex-Gov. Jackson, whose family reside at Salisbury during the summer.
There was some little disturbance at the hotel that night, owing to the fact
that the room of two of the banjo club men had been wrecked. There was an
exciting battle on the third floor for a while, but it was interrupted several times

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

by visits of the proprietor. The men were at length quieted, and the two unfortunates of the banjo club were sent to bed in another room by Mr Snake,
the irate host.
It was hard for the men to get up at 6.30 Friday morning, but they had to
do it. A few of the men were so completely carried off their feet by the charms
of Cambridge and Easton that they could not resist the temptation to go back
there, but the majority returned via Claiborne to Baltimore, arriving here at 2
P. M. Friday.
The men taken were:
Messrs. R. C. Pagon, Jackson, Humrichouse, Carver, Marshall, Bryan,
Gilman, Hall, Ford, CoNites, Martin, Randall, Mason, Engle, Eveland, Coffin,
Winter, l,angnecker, Redewill, Baetjer, Nelson, Lanier, Snowden, Hendry,
Bird, Plaggemyer, Geiger, W. W. Pagon and Super.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES.
HE morning prayer service is led this week by J. M. Motley. It is hoped
that during this coming term more men will avail themselves of this opportunity for a few moments of worship. Men with 9 o'clock hour on can
often get in at 8.45 if they will think of it The singing is good but more voices
will help. R. P. Stephens leads next week.

t

The end this week brings to us a man of very marked ability, power, and
experience. It is planned that next Sunday, January t ith, at 3.30, T. Jays,
Esq., St. Thomas' Hospital, London, Eng , will speak to college men. We
have invited all the other Baltimore colleges to meet with us and if Hopkins
men do their part to hold up a good reputation for Hopkins the upstairs room
in Levering Hall should be filled. Mr. Jays represents the British student
work and is on leave of absence for this year to travel for the American Student
Volunteer movement among our colleges. Those of us who met hi in last year
recall our great pleasure. We wish the same for all who will avail themselves
of this opportunity. Mr. Jays will be in town several days and be very glad to
meet as many men personally as possible.
He comes to us as a fellow student who has worked for a number of years
as missionary in Western Africa, and now returned to complete the medical
course. At the end of his course he returns to the African position. His stories
of difficulties, dangers and privations met with and the triumphs of the Gospel
among those people are facinating. One feels their force aad influence from the
strong personality of the man. All men not :.fraid of such a presentation are
urged to take this opportunity.
Any man who run across an opportunity for a handbook “add" are urged
to pick it up and mention to J. L. Bennet or the General Secretary.
The Graduate Student Bible Class will succeed Dr. Foote's Class Meeting
at the same time and place, Dilhnan Library, 3rd floor McCoo Hall, every
Thursday at 5 o'clock. Topics will be prepared by the committee.
The General Secretary or Mr. L C. Barret would like to have the names
of any men who would like to have a series of daily Bible readings to follow
through the year.

ITH this issue a change will be noted in the staff of the Nuws LETTER.
Mr. Robert S. Lanier relinquishes his position as head of the paper in
order to devote his entire time to the Hullabaloo. It is with regret
that his co workers on the NEWS-LETTER part company with their editor-inchief. Since his first year at the University lie has been an energetic, efficient
worker for the good of the paper, devoting to it his time and talent with unstinted measure, The N itws LETTER loses him only that he may devote himself to the labors which the class of 1903 has declared to be peculiarly his own.
While Mr.. Lanier made no radical changes in the policy pursued by his
predecessors, he has strengthened the paper by his careful attention to the various departments of college life and by securing a series of leading articles which
have been of timely ,interest to the student body. His editorials, liberal in tone
and free from class or ,fractional bias, bore witness to his thorough acquaintance
with all phases of University life and to a jealous regard for its customs and traditions.
From now until within a few weeks of the close of the college year Mr.
Lanier will be engaged in editing the Hullabaloo. With such an editor-in-chief
the class of 1903 makes no idle boast in declaring that the Hullabaloo this season will be far superior to any previous year-book.

ero

THU N EWS—LETTUR,

7

In his management of the paper the NEWS-LITTER feels that Mr. Lanier
has given promise of a useful literary career In him was found that rare combination of literary talent and executive ability which gives assurance of future
success in the field of letters. The NEWS LETTER does not doubt but that future
editors of this paper will feel an honest thrill of pride on thinking that they are
working on the same paper which Bob" Lanier once edited.

HE lacrosse situation at present cannot be said to call forth the enthusiasm
of its follows. Captain Straus is doing his part, the old men are as conscientious as ever, and the coach is painstaking and careful with all who
requires his attention. The serious trouble lies with the new men. During
the past month General Apathy has been making a vigorous campaign among
them. Few took the trouble to come out, and those few evinced a surprising
lack of interest in the game. Considering that the Freshmen were facing their
first examinations something may be pardoned them; yet it seems strange that
they could not find some time to devote to Hopkins' greatest game. The old
men cannot play on forever, new blood must be injected from time to time, and
the members of the Freshman Class are to supply this new blood. It would be
a disgrace to the class and to the University as well if they refused to accept
the burdens which college life imposes upon them. A man who can work but
persists in shirking his duty is not worthy of a place among us. This is the beginning of a new term and it is to be hoped that a new spirit will animate the
new men from the very first. The game is a facinating one, and well repays
the time and attention one may bestow upon it.
The track team, also, has not had its full quota of new men at all times.
As in the case of the lacrosse team the old guard has been faithfully at work.
During the holidays scarcely a day passed but what some of the old men were
at work in the cage. With the inter class games not more than three weeks off
each class ought to get out as many men as possible, for every point will count.
Besides that, these games will be excellent prrctice for the new men; they will
give a feeling of confidence which will be of great advantage when the time
comes to run in competition with outsiders.
The NEWS-LETTER has no desire to preach, but it cannot refrain from
uttering a word of warning and advice to the new men.
UST at present the question of a debate with the Leland Stanford, Jr.,
University is being agitated. To the NEWS-LETTER the idea of going
quite across the continent at the present time seems senseless, if not to
say ridiculous, when we can find at our own doors so many foemen worthy of
our steel, What end cin be furthered by debating with Leland Stanford, which
would not be subserved as well by debating with some college nearer home?
We shall have our hands full in preparing for the debate with North Carolina.
Whatever time may be available after this one is concluded could well be devoted to a debate with some other college, but why it is necessary to go to
Leland Stanford is beyond our comprehension.

MR. R. BRENT KEYSER ELECTED PRESIDENT OF THE BOARD

OF TRUSTEES.
T the meeting of the Board of Trustees, held on last Monday, Mr. R.
Brent Keyser was elected president to succeed Mr. James L. McLane,
who resigned some time ago. Mr. Francis White, who is one of the
original Board of Trustees, and who has been acting as president since
Mr. McLane's resignation when into effect, was elected president, but declined
the honor, as he felt that it would be better for a younger and more active man
to have the place. Mr. Keyser was then elected. He was chosen a member of
the Board last May, and since then has taken an active interest in the affairs of
the University.
At the meeting President Remsen delivered his annual report to the trustees. He stated that the University was free from debt, and that there never
was a time when the University had been unable to meet its obligations. It
was announced that the million dollar fund would not be wholly available for
use until the end of the present academic year.

ANNUAL CONVENTION OF MODERN LANGUAGE ASSOCIATION
OF AMERICA.
N the last three days of December the University was the host of a distinguished body of men literary and linguistic scholars, the members of
the Modern Language Association of. America. The convention was a
Hopkins affair since, with one exception. all the meetings were held in McCoy
Hall, and from the fact that University men have always taken a prominent
part in the association. Dr. A. Marshall Elliott was the first secretary of the
association, which office he filled from 1883 to 1892, and on his resignation Dr.
James W. Bright was elected to succeed him, and in turn carried on the work
for nine more years. Last year Dr. Bright resigned and was elected to the
presidency, as Dr. Elliott had been before him.
The association was called to order by President Bright on the afternoon of
December 29. In the absence of President Remsen, who was in Washington

N the evening of December 23, a feed was held at the Hullabaloo Club.
The feature of the evening was a song by Mr. Mackdermott, ably
seconded by Jack Nelson. At a seasonable hour a turkey dinner was
served by s caterer.
H. K. Tootle has severed his connection with the "Baltimore American."
The editors of the "Hullabaloo" recently requested President Woodrow
Wilson, of Princeton, to write their leading article, but President Wilson was
compelled to refuse on account of being pressed for time.
The Debating Club has sent a proposal to the students of Leland Stand ford,
Jr., University for a series of three annual debates preferably on some phase of
the tariff question. The first to take place at Leland Stanford, the second at the
Hopkins, and the third at some intermediate point. The proposal will be considered by the Leland Stanford Debating Club in the early part of this month.
The Senior Class is preparing to hold its annual class banquet. It is not
execred to be as interesting as last year's banquet. Yet every one is guaranteed
a good time. H. W. Plaggemeyer will be the toast master.
Carroll M. Sparrow, a former member of '03, sailed on the third of the
month for Porto Rico to take soundings on the southwest coast for the United
States Coast and Geodetic Survey.

LACROSSE OUTLOOK.
OW that the ordeal of the Christmas examinations and the dissipation ot
the holidays is over, the captains of the lacrosse and of the track and
field teams will have a right to the attention of the men for several
months to come. In the direction of lacrosse particularly, Captain Henry
Strauss purposes continuing systematic work in the cage until the first signs of
Spring appear, and the candidates are able to turn out at Druid Hill Park.
The first practice this year was held in the cage Tuesday afternoon, and a
very encouraging squad put in appearance.
A feeling of reticence, however, still seems to exist among the freshmen,
for '05 turned out a very small percentage of the whole squad There is certainly no good reason for this, for the class is large and contains quite a number
of well-developed men. Smoke up, freshmen! "It's up to you."
As regards prospects, the outlook is decidedly better than it appeared at
the close of the season last year. Several of the candidates—notably those
from the junior ranks—are showing up remarkably well Briscoe, the goal
veteran, may return in a few weeks; Ranft, of the 1901 team, declares his
insention of trying for a position on the twelve; and Captain Strauss with a
knowing smile tias one or two other trump cards up his sleeve, which will not
be divulged at present.
.
Just as was the case in football last fall, the lacrosse team also needs a fast
scrub, and it behooves every new man to come out and learn to handle a stick.
It is an obligation due the University.
The usual uncertainty still exists in regard to th-1, schedule for the season.
The dates with Swarthmore and Stevens Institute are certain, but Lehigh wants
to play later in the season, and Cornell is apparently by no means anxious to
line up against Hopkins on her own grounds The Crescent Athletic Club is
also due here in May, and a reply from Oxford, England, is expected every
day. Besides these two brilliant exhibition games, a third will probably be
added in the direcLion of the Toronto twelve. It is more than likely that the
Canadians will repeat their visit to Baltimore for another contest in June.
With a collegiate league composed of four teams and such exhibition games
as the foregoing, the season should be the greatest in the history of lacrosse at
Johns Hopkins.
Let every man come out and hustle! There's a feeling of duty well-discharged as well as all kinds of glory in it.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
TRACT TEAM AT WORK.

T the present time it is not possible to give a very definite account of the
affairs of the Track Team, as it is only in a formative period. On the
first day after the holidays, regular systematic work was renewed. The
cage once again began to assume its old-time business-like appearance. Straggling in from all directions came embryo record-breakers and old stagers to put
themselves under the tender care of "Pather Bill," who must discover and
develop the best that is in them. Previous to this the training has been of a
desultory nature. However, from now on, hard, steady, unterrupted by holidays, will be strictly observed. The work, light at first, will gradually be
increased until the best possible results are obtained.
No definite plans for the future have as yet been formulated. One idea to
be highly commended is the proposed holding of Interclass games in the cage.
The events, if found practicable, would probably include relay races, 30 yard
dash, 440 yard, one half and one mile run, high jump and shot-put. Aside
from furnishing amusement to the spectators, arousing interest, and perhaps
raising funds, they have a very important influence upon the general work of
the Track Team. They will undoubtedly stimulate interest in track work and
bring out men whose ability is as yet unknown even to themselves. A little
friendly class rivalry will sometimes stir up class and college spirit that can be
reached in no other way, and when once aroused it is not likely to decrease,
but give vent to itself in many ways.
Just here in connection with interclass games, it may not he altogether out
of place to say a word about the recent cane-rush—that was not. The 6th of
December, the Christmas holidays, and the beginning of the second term are all
things of the past. But what of the cane-rush! Is it a thing of the future?
Everybody seems to know less about it than everybody else. The silence on
the subject from some quarters has become so oppressive that it can almost be
felt. The facts in the case are becoming more and more complicated, and are
gradually giving way to vague rumors. Now that the holidays are over, it is
time that some definite action be taken in the matter. Speak up, someone, and
relieve the suspense of those concerned.

THE WORTH OF KNOWING ONE'S SELF.
HIS season of the year brings the business man a time for counting up the
.debit and credit columns in order to ascertain where he stands and to
learn the strength of his position; with him it is a literal stock taking and
settlement of his affairs for a new year. With us, as students, it is a period of
renewed resolution to live nearer the ideals which we have set for ourselves
either in scholarship or in refinement of life or in other mental occupations
with which our life is brought into immediate contact. The student comes to
college to learn the meaning of introspection; to investigate the bearing which
things outside of himself have towards his own inner mental being; to grasp in
some limited measure the significance of the great world drama which has been
Playing from eternity and whose finale, whose denouement is that "grand event
towards which the whole creation moves." No wonder, therefore, if at this
Opening of a new year we moralize and reflect upon what we are, why we are
here and ask ourselves whither we are tending. Like the merchant we take
an inventory, although of quite another kind than his. The result of our reck
oning should be a balance of what points of strength we possess against the
Points of weakness. As human beings we are a bundle of forces that resist,
that overcome and which finally spend themselves in resistance. Powers of
mind and of body go hand in hand, so to speak, through life guided with
varying degrees of mastership according to the individual contesting them. As
our physical forces wane our mental strength, toward our later life, should
exhibit a firmness and suppleness in direct ratio to our years and accompany
our failing bodies to brighten their existence and raise them from bitterness.
The declining age of a man who has trusted his sensual life for satisfaction,
whether in business or pleasure or idle ease, must be, logically, physical and
mental wretchedness. Now, realizing ourselves as endowed with these ele.
ments of strength which, by some inscrutable law, must spend themselves, must
objectify themselves in visible or rather tangible demonstration, we can reckon
with ourselves as to what parts of our being need more attention than others.
In other words, what are our points of weakness; what forces in our nature are
liable to show least resistance. The human frame, as we call it, falls asunder
not by the utter collapse of all the parts—bones, muscles and nerves—but owing
to the frailty of a single weakness, which entails entire dissolution and which
the forces of the system collectively cannot stay. Any material object, in like
manner, follows precisely the same law. In the moral world the phenomena of
strength and weakness also appears. It may be the Greeks meant to convey a
lesson to their youth of the importance of watching the weak point in character
by the portrayal of Hercules writhing under a tunic which his world-lifting

2

THE NEWS-LETTER•

strength could not remove. Or the picture of Achilles might have afforded the
same moral when that flower of Greek military prowess was made to meet death
at the hands of Paris who happened to direct the arrow against his invulnerable
body. The hero fell because his heel had not been bathed in the stream whose
waters had saved him from ten thousand arrows hitherto. It may be also that
Samson's career and its sequel conveys a meaning similar to that of Hercules
or Achilles. We can infer that if these giants of myth and history fell at the
point of their greatest weakness, then our lives are subject to the same general
conditions as theirs. The unexpected, the unforseen contingencies are those
which, appearing suddenly as they do, strike at us and may prove too much for
the resistance we can offer them. As students, we need strength to sustain the
courage of conviction, and very frequently at times when, unawares, we stand
confronted with a difficulty that only immediate courage can surmount.
There is a moral sang-froid as well as a mental. Not that a man is to burden
himself with a suspicion of danger impending, and to let the dread of it cast a
cloud over his life-----on the contrary—to face with calmness any emergency that
may arise and despatch it cheerfully. A coward walks backwards into greater
dangers frequently than he would if he went forward, simply because he can see
where he is going w hen he faces the trouble he has to meet and might avert it
largely. One of the forces we cultivate in college life is perseverance, which
is a phase of bravery; bravery, because after efforts made and repeated almost
to the point of physical pain we succeed in overturning and -laying out" the
difficulty that baffles during long hours. Milton is said to have passed scarcely

training we receive at college,
that responsibiliiy falls to guide the forces inherent in our nature along the lines
of courage, perseverance and restraint; to make us masters of ourselves and
husband our energies according to reason; to teach us the lesson of self confidence plus a tranquility of bearing that marks a gentleman. Then,once started
in the direction of these attainments we grow into the educated man if
though we forget every word of Latin and Greek that we ever
thumbed out of a lexicon. If this short paper were a fragment of a treatise on
ethics which it is obviously not, the argument might prove how such a training
of the forces in a man's self reacted upon him and the race at large to the making of a better community in which he should chance to live. The important
point of all is that, adding to his common sense, (which if Ile lack, no eduction
were better in his case) the results gained from his intercourse with instructors
and fellow students and from conscientious painstaking with the very few books
rerched in three years' study, a student should go into the world with a
thoroughly healthful realization of his own strength and weakness and should
be prepared to stand his ground cheerfully and firmly. In the natural course of
events a student, when once left to his own resources ought to develope and
survive as against one who has never been apprised of his failings; his standard
of what a man is being higher than that of his unlettered neighbor requires of him
greater action and should guard him against the shocks of experience by leading him to resist them with equanimity. Fortitude can cope with odds and bear
defeat; brute strength gives way almost immediately on meeting a force but
slightly greater than its own—the one is intelligent strength while the other
lacks intelligence, and the college man who leaves his Alma Mater a stranger
to the meaning of this has to begin life on the level of boyhood.

THE CHRISTMAS TRIP OF THE MUSICAL CLUBS.
44froHAT! going to the Eastern Shore?"
.
This was the disgusted comment of most of the men when they
heard that the management of the University Glee, Banjo, and
Mandolin Clubs had decided to take in Cambridge, Easton, and Salisbury this
year, instead of the usual jaunt to the Valley of Virginia. Most of the men,
however, had evidently never experienced true Eastern Shore hospitality before, and a pleasant surprise awaited them, for the trip was the most enjoyable
Christmas trip ever taken by the clubs, and the most successful, artistically and
financially.
The clubs, numbering 29 musicians of no mean ability, left Baltimore for
Cambridge Monday, December 29th, on the steamer "Avalon." The journey
down the bay was not without incident The development of certain athletic
tendencies'by one of the heretofore solely literary and social lights of the clubs
merely goes to subs,antiate the fact that a college education certainly does
broaden one's scope.
When the clubs arrived at Cambridge, the men were invited to stay with
many of the prominent old families there, and, of course, had a royal time.
Three dances in twenty hours ought to be a record, if it isn't. But even greater
than the number of dances were the attractions and charms of Cambridge's
beauteous daughters. The men, partfcularly one of them, completely lost their
hearts in this old storehouse of Dorchester County's history.
The next place visited was Easton The same cordial welcome awaited
the clubs here. After the concert, which was the best of the three, Mrs. Os—
wald Tilghman gave a fine dance, lasting well on into the New Year, at her
residence. The house was a splendid one for the inevitable tele-a-tete, and the
men made the best of their opportunities.
To the accompaniment of sobs from the fair maidens, the men took their
leave of Easton Thursday morning. Our manager was so broken up at parting
that he forgot most of his belongings, and had to return for them later. The
trip to Salisbury was pleasant, the engine at times attaining the remarkable
speed of iso
miles an hour. Contrary to the precedent of all other Christmas
trips, the prevailing card-game wfis whist. Some of the upper-clasmen devoted
part of their time to the study of the education of the young, and all that one
had to do when an attendant was wanted was to blow a whistle, and a freshman
immediately ran up to get his orders.
The afternoon at Salisbury was spent in making calls and drinking eggnogg. The certainly know how to brew it across the bay.
The crowd at the Salisbury concert was the largest one of the trip. After
the concert was over, a most enjoyable Eastern Shore dinner was given by
Richard N. Jackson, '05, son of Ex-Gov. Jackson, whose family reside at Salisbury during the summer.
There was some little disturbance at the hotel that night, owing to the fact
that the room of two of the banjo club men had been wrecked. There was an
exciting battle on the third floor for a while, but it was interrupted several times

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

by visits of the proprietor. The men were at length quieted, and the two unfortunates of the banjo club were sent to bed in another room by Mr Snake,
the irate host.
It was hard for the men to get up at 6.30 Friday morning, but they had to
do it. A few of the men were so completely carried off their feet by the charms
of Cambridge and Easton that they could not resist the temptation to go back
there, but the majority returned via Claiborne to Baltimore, arriving here at 2
P. M. Friday.
The men taken were:

Winter, l,angnecker, Redewill, Baetjer, Nelson, Lanier, Snowden, Hendry,
Bird, Plaggemyer, Geiger, W. W. Pagon and Super.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES.
HE morning prayer service is led this week by J. M. Motley. It is hoped
that during this coming term more men will avail themselves of this opportunity for a few moments of worship. Men with 9 o'clock hour on can
often get in at 8.45 if they will think of it The singing is good but more voices
will help. R. P. Stephens leads next week.

t

The end this week brings to us a man of very marked ability, power, and
experience. It is planned that next Sunday, January t ith, at 3.30, T. Jays,
Esq., St. Thomas' Hospital, London, Eng , will speak to college men. We
have invited all the other Baltimore colleges to meet with us and if Hopkins
men do their part to hold up a good reputation for Hopkins the upstairs room
in Levering Hall should be filled. Mr. Jays represents the British student
work and is on leave of absence for this year to travel for the American Student
Volunteer movement among our colleges. Those of us who met hi in last year
recall our great pleasure. We wish the same for all who will avail themselves
of this opportunity. Mr. Jays will be in town several days and be very glad to
meet as many men personally as possible.
He comes to us as a fellow student who has worked for a number of years
as missionary in Western Africa, and now returned to complete the medical
course. At the end of his course he returns to the African position. His stories
of difficulties, dangers and privations met with and the triumphs of the Gospel
among those people are facinating. One feels their force aad influence from the
strong personality of the man. All men not :.fraid of such a presentation are
urged to take this opportunity.
Any man who run across an opportunity for a handbook “add" are urged
to pick it up and mention to J. L. Bennet or the General Secretary.
The Graduate Student Bible Class will succeed Dr. Foote's Class Meeting
at the same time and place, Dilhnan Library, 3rd floor McCoo Hall, every
Thursday at 5 o'clock. Topics will be prepared by the committee.
The General Secretary or Mr. L C. Barret would like to have the names
of any men who would like to have a series of daily Bible readings to follow
through the year.

ITH this issue a change will be noted in the staff of the Nuws LETTER.
Mr. Robert S. Lanier relinquishes his position as head of the paper in
order to devote his entire time to the Hullabaloo. It is with regret
that his co workers on the NEWS-LETTER part company with their editor-inchief. Since his first year at the University lie has been an energetic, efficient
worker for the good of the paper, devoting to it his time and talent with unstinted measure, The N itws LETTER loses him only that he may devote himself to the labors which the class of 1903 has declared to be peculiarly his own.
While Mr.. Lanier made no radical changes in the policy pursued by his
predecessors, he has strengthened the paper by his careful attention to the various departments of college life and by securing a series of leading articles which
have been of timely ,interest to the student body. His editorials, liberal in tone
and free from class or ,fractional bias, bore witness to his thorough acquaintance
with all phases of University life and to a jealous regard for its customs and traditions.
From now until within a few weeks of the close of the college year Mr.
Lanier will be engaged in editing the Hullabaloo. With such an editor-in-chief
the class of 1903 makes no idle boast in declaring that the Hullabaloo this season will be far superior to any previous year-book.

has given promise of a useful literary career In him was found that rare combination of literary talent and executive ability which gives assurance of future

editors of this paper will feel an honest thrill of pride on thinking that they are
working on the same paper which Bob" Lanier once edited.

HE lacrosse situation at present cannot be said to call forth the enthusiasm
of its follows. Captain Straus is doing his part, the old men are as conscientious as ever, and the coach is painstaking and careful with all who
requires his attention. The serious trouble lies with the new men. During
the past month General Apathy has been making a vigorous campaign among
them. Few took the trouble to come out, and those few evinced a surprising
lack of interest in the game. Considering that the Freshmen were facing their
first examinations something may be pardoned them; yet it seems strange that
they could not find some time to devote to Hopkins' greatest game. The old
men cannot play on forever, new blood must be injected from time to time, and
the members of the Freshman Class are to supply this new blood. It would be
a disgrace to the class and to the University as well if they refused to accept
the burdens which college life imposes upon them. A man who can work but
persists in shirking his duty is not worthy of a place among us. This is the beginning of a new term and it is to be hoped that a new spirit will animate the
new men from the very first. The game is a facinating one, and well repays
the time and attention one may bestow upon it.
The track team, also, has not had its full quota of new men at all times.
As in the case of the lacrosse team the old guard has been faithfully at work.
During the holidays scarcely a day passed but what some of the old men were
at work in the cage. With the inter class games not more than three weeks off
each class ought to get out as many men as possible, for every point will count.
Besides that, these games will be excellent prrctice for the new men; they will
give a feeling of confidence which will be of great advantage when the time
comes to run in competition with outsiders.
The NEWS-LETTER has no desire to preach, but it cannot refrain from
uttering a word of warning and advice to the new men.
UST at present the question of a debate with the Leland Stanford, Jr.,
University is being agitated. To the NEWS-LETTER the idea of going
quite across the continent at the present time seems senseless, if not to
say ridiculous, when we can find at our own doors so many foemen worthy of
our steel, What end cin be furthered by debating with Leland Stanford, which
would not be subserved as well by debating with some college nearer home?
We shall have our hands full in preparing for the debate with North Carolina.
Whatever time may be available after this one is concluded could well be devoted to a debate with some other college, but why it is necessary to go to
Leland Stanford is beyond our comprehension.

T the meeting of the Board of Trustees, held on last Monday, Mr. R.
Brent Keyser was elected president to succeed Mr. James L. McLane,
who resigned some time ago. Mr. Francis White, who is one of the
original Board of Trustees, and who has been acting as president since
Mr. McLane's resignation when into effect, was elected president, but declined
the honor, as he felt that it would be better for a younger and more active man
to have the place. Mr. Keyser was then elected. He was chosen a member of
the Board last May, and since then has taken an active interest in the affairs of
the University.
At the meeting President Remsen delivered his annual report to the trustees. He stated that the University was free from debt, and that there never
was a time when the University had been unable to meet its obligations. It
was announced that the million dollar fund would not be wholly available for
use until the end of the present academic year.

R. C. E. WALTERS headed a delegation of Baltimoreans at the first meet
ing of the Wild Flower Preservatioh Society of America held in Washington on December 27.
The University was well represented at the annual convention of the
American Association for the Advancement of Science, held in Washington last
week. As president of the association Dr Ira Remsen presided, and responded
to the address of welcome, and delivered the principle address at the second
days' session, when he spoke on "The History of a Doctrine." Others in attendance from the University were: Drs. D. C. Gilman, Wm. B. Clark, Wm.
11. Welch, 0. L. 1-.'assig, and Mr. A. W. Smith.
Dean Griffin recently addressed the Methodist Episcopal ministers meeting
on "Recreative Reading."
Dr. Gilman presided at the public meeting of the Woman's Auxiliary of
the Maryland Civil Service Reform Association, held in McCoy Hall on the
night of January 5.
Harlan Updegraff, A. M., last year assistant to Nicholas Murray Butler,
President of Columbia University, will lecture before the Pedagogical Society
Saturday, January 17, at It A. M., in the Donovan Room.

ANNUAL CONVENTION OF MODERN LANGUAGE ASSOCIATION
OF AMERICA.
N the last three days of December the University was the host of a distinguished body of men literary and linguistic scholars, the members of
the Modern Language Association of. America. The convention was a
Hopkins affair since, with one exception. all the meetings were held in McCoy
Hall, and from the fact that University men have always taken a prominent
part in the association. Dr. A. Marshall Elliott was the first secretary of the
association, which office he filled from 1883 to 1892, and on his resignation Dr.
James W. Bright was elected to succeed him, and in turn carried on the work
for nine more years. Last year Dr. Bright resigned and was elected to the
presidency, as Dr. Elliott had been before him.
The association was called to order by President Bright on the afternoon of
December 29. In the absence of President Remsen, who was in Washington

UNDERGRADUATE NOTES.

O

N the evening of December 23, a feed was held at the Hullabaloo Club.
The feature of the evening was a song by Mr. Mackdermott, ably
seconded by Jack Nelson. At a seasonable hour a turkey dinner was
served by s caterer.
H. K. Tootle has severed his connection with the "Baltimore American."
The editors of the "Hullabaloo" recently requested President Woodrow
Wilson, of Princeton, to write their leading article, but President Wilson was
compelled to refuse on account of being pressed for time.
The Debating Club has sent a proposal to the students of Leland Stand ford,
Jr., University for a series of three annual debates preferably on some phase of
the tariff question. The first to take place at Leland Stanford, the second at the
Hopkins, and the third at some intermediate point. The proposal will be considered by the Leland Stanford Debating Club in the early part of this month.
The Senior Class is preparing to hold its annual class banquet. It is not
execred to be as interesting as last year's banquet. Yet every one is guaranteed
a good time. H. W. Plaggemeyer will be the toast master.
Carroll M. Sparrow, a former member of '03, sailed on the third of the
month for Porto Rico to take soundings on the southwest coast for the United
States Coast and Geodetic Survey.

The editors of the "Hullabaloo" request that the members of the Senior
Class have their pictures taken as soon as possible. A prompt compliance with
this request will greatly facilitaie the work of the hoard.
T. Wesley Glocker is still confined to his home with a severe attack of
tonsilitis.
The musical clubs will give a concert, January 13, at the Homestead Methodist Episcopal Church.
The fiat has gone forth that there must be no more smoking in Walter's
barber shop. Alas, where now will the loafers congregate to woe my Lady
Nicotine? Walter has not burst forth into one of his philosophical discourses
replete with wisdom, but he has promised a contribution on smokers and the
gentle art of smoking for the next issue.
The question for debate between Hopkins and the University of North Carolina has at last been agreed upon. We take the affirmative of the question,
Resolved, That our merchant marine should not be subsidized.

LACROSSE OUTLOOK.
OW that the ordeal of the Christmas examinations and the dissipation ot
the holidays is over, the captains of the lacrosse and of the track and
field teams will have a right to the attention of the men for several
months to come. In the direction of lacrosse particularly, Captain Henry
Strauss purposes continuing systematic work in the cage until the first signs of
Spring appear, and the candidates are able to turn out at Druid Hill Park.
The first practice this year was held in the cage Tuesday afternoon, and a
very encouraging squad put in appearance.
A feeling of reticence, however, still seems to exist among the freshmen,
for '05 turned out a very small percentage of the whole squad There is certainly no good reason for this, for the class is large and contains quite a number
of well-developed men. Smoke up, freshmen! "It's up to you."
As regards prospects, the outlook is decidedly better than it appeared at
the close of the season last year. Several of the candidates—notably those
from the junior ranks—are showing up remarkably well Briscoe, the goal
veteran, may return in a few weeks; Ranft, of the 1901 team, declares his
insention of trying for a position on the twelve; and Captain Strauss with a
knowing smile tias one or two other trump cards up his sleeve, which will not
be divulged at present.
.
Just as was the case in football last fall, the lacrosse team also needs a fast
scrub, and it behooves every new man to come out and learn to handle a stick.
It is an obligation due the University.
The usual uncertainty still exists in regard to th-1, schedule for the season.
The dates with Swarthmore and Stevens Institute are certain, but Lehigh wants
to play later in the season, and Cornell is apparently by no means anxious to
line up against Hopkins on her own grounds The Crescent Athletic Club is
also due here in May, and a reply from Oxford, England, is expected every
day. Besides these two brilliant exhibition games, a third will probably be
added in the direcLion of the Toronto twelve. It is more than likely that the
Canadians will repeat their visit to Baltimore for another contest in June.
With a collegiate league composed of four teams and such exhibition games
as the foregoing, the season should be the greatest in the history of lacrosse at
Johns Hopkins.
Let every man come out and hustle! There's a feeling of duty well-discharged as well as all kinds of glory in it.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
TRACT TEAM AT WORK.

T the present time it is not possible to give a very definite account of the
affairs of the Track Team, as it is only in a formative period. On the
first day after the holidays, regular systematic work was renewed. The
cage once again began to assume its old-time business-like appearance. Straggling in from all directions came embryo record-breakers and old stagers to put
themselves under the tender care of "Pather Bill," who must discover and
develop the best that is in them. Previous to this the training has been of a
desultory nature. However, from now on, hard, steady, unterrupted by holidays, will be strictly observed. The work, light at first, will gradually be
increased until the best possible results are obtained.
No definite plans for the future have as yet been formulated. One idea to
be highly commended is the proposed holding of Interclass games in the cage.
The events, if found practicable, would probably include relay races, 30 yard
dash, 440 yard, one half and one mile run, high jump and shot-put. Aside
from furnishing amusement to the spectators, arousing interest, and perhaps
raising funds, they have a very important influence upon the general work of
the Track Team. They will undoubtedly stimulate interest in track work and
bring out men whose ability is as yet unknown even to themselves. A little
friendly class rivalry will sometimes stir up class and college spirit that can be
reached in no other way, and when once aroused it is not likely to decrease,
but give vent to itself in many ways.
Just here in connection with interclass games, it may not he altogether out
of place to say a word about the recent cane-rush—that was not. The 6th of
December, the Christmas holidays, and the beginning of the second term are all
things of the past. But what of the cane-rush! Is it a thing of the future?
Everybody seems to know less about it than everybody else. The silence on
the subject from some quarters has become so oppressive that it can almost be
felt. The facts in the case are becoming more and more complicated, and are
gradually giving way to vague rumors. Now that the holidays are over, it is
time that some definite action be taken in the matter. Speak up, someone, and
relieve the suspense of those concerned.

daybreak. The police used clubs and revolvers and two medical students were
